article: I decided not to bring in home any other things with the words Made in China on a dark Monday, two days after last Christmas, though I still keep some in my house. At work my boss, Mr. White, points out that I am  _  myself if I think I have been  _  Chinese products, in spite of the obvious facts in daily life. "Chinese  _  are everywhere," he says, "You can't avoid those, no matter how hard you try, it is impossible." That is the  _  , which I have been considering for months, since I have kept the American car with the Chinese  _  in it. This week I was  _  again of the difficulty of avoiding China when I bought earrings from a local artist. I was feeling pleased with myself  _  I got home and noticed the gift box made in China. My boss continues, "You know what you are doing? You are  _  your dependence on China, not  _  it," he says, "You are just cheating yourself." The boss, a frequent complainer, doesn't slow down when I  _  to stop him to  _  that I am writing a  _  of stories on the boycott for the business magazine. "Maybe you can  _  it a year without Chinese products,  _  sooner or later you will even  _  Chinese dishes," the nice boss says, "There is no getting around it." I  _  at him as he turns to leave, quite  _  . "Thanks for your support," I say to his  _  . The year is nearly half over. I can  _  without them.  _  , it is a little inconvenient to live without a DVD player, a DV camera or a printer made in China. But a better question might be: How hard could it be to live without Made in China with the whole family?
